Bart.Action: Leads co-workers in an upbeat, stylish song performance, engaging them positively.
Pretends not to know traditional songs to mock overseers' expectations, involving co-workers in the act.
Leads his co-workers in a clever, unexpected musical performance that confuses and frustrates the overseers, demonstrating quick thinking and control of the situation.
Feigns ignorance of the overseers' demands and plays along with the confusion, showing strategic use of humor and social intelligence.
Responds to a demeaning order by complying but adds a humorous, personal story about his grandmother, sharing a joke with Charlie.
Obeys order to test the ground by riding the handcar despite the danger, showing willingness to take initiative and follow instructions.
Engages in casual, off-topic banter about his grandmother while on a serious task, which could indicate a lack of focus.
Calls out for help in a dire situation, showing concern for survival.
Makes a grim joke about quicksand, showing a dark sense of humor but no malice.
Recognizes they are sinking in quicksand and correctly identifies the danger with a clear, somewhat humorous explanation.
Calls for help persistently while trapped in quicksand, showing awareness of the situation and attempt to get rescued.
Does not demonstrate any immediate plan or attempt to escape quicksand beyond calling for help.
Strains to reach an overhanging branch to save himself and Charlie from quicksand.
Expresses frustration by calling Taggart a 'stupid sonova-bitch' when Taggart prioritizes the handcar over their safety.
In a last desperate effort, manages to grab onto the handcar and is pulled out of quicksand with Charlie.
Strains to reach an overhanging branch but fails and is mocked by Taggart.
Expresses frustration and demands help aggressively ('Hey you stupid sonova-bitch, what about us?').
Grabs shovel and takes vicious practice swings, then smashes Taggart on the head with it.
Grabs shovel and takes vicious practice swings, then smashes Taggart on the head with the shovel, effectively incapacitating him.
Acts decisively and confidently in a dangerous situation, showing quick thinking and boldness.
Politely suggests waiting his turn before being hanged, showing consideration for others.
Engages in light humor with Boris about a blindfold or after dinner mint, indicating a friendly and good-natured demeanor.
Calmly negotiates with the guard about waiting his turn to be hanged, showing presence of mind in a tense situation.
Asks Boris if there is any reprieve available, demonstrating quick thinking and attempt to change his fate.
Requests last words and leads a prayer before hanging, showing respect and sincerity.
Uses the prayer moment to quietly escape, demonstrating cleverness but also a lack of direct confrontation or aggression.
Calmly uses a clever ruse of prayer to distract the officials and quietly escapes from being hanged.
Maintains composure and confidence when confronted by Hedley Lamarr with a gun, showing situational awareness.
Accepts the sheriff's badge and surveys the scene impassively, indicating readiness and confidence.
Sits quietly in the corner when introduced as the new sheriff despite hostile and racist remarks.
Sits calmly in the corner when confronted with hostility and skepticism about his appointment as sheriff.
Does not react defensively or with panic to Le Petomane's racist remarks and doubts.
Arrives in town confidently dressed in spectacular, stylish attire, showing self-assurance and flair.
Tips his hat in acknowledgement to the townspeople despite their frozen horror and shock at his arrival.
Uses humor with the line 'Excuse me, while I whip this out,' causing a woman to scream and faint.
Rides confidently into town despite hostile or shocked crowd, calmly dismounts and ascends speaker's platform.
Uses humor and dramatic timing by saying 'Excuse me, while I whip this out' before revealing the proclamation, diffusing tension.
Maintains composure and authority while reading the official proclamation to a tense crowd.
Shows clear fear but uses a bluff to prevent violence and protect himself and others.
Uses a racial slur and adopts a cringing, whining plantation darkie voice to intimidate townspeople.
Raises his eyebrows, showing awareness of impending danger.
Quickens pace of speech to assert authority as sheriff.
Whips out his gun and pretends to threaten himself to intimidate the townspeople.
Is clearly frightened and closes his eyes tightly, showing internal fear.
Calms the townspeople by telling them to throw down their guns gently, trying to de-escalate the situation.
Threatens to shoot Van Jotinson if he doesn't drop his rifle, using harsh language.
Warns Van with a warning shot near his head, showing control and restraint rather than immediate violence.
Commands the townspeople to throw down their guns confidently and manages to de-escalate a tense situation.
Spots a man on the roof raising a rifle and quickly commands him to drop it, successfully preventing an attack.
Backs down the street slowly while maintaining control and awareness of his surroundings.
Makes a sudden run for the jail but immediately stops himself when shot near his head, showing quick reflexes and understanding of limits.
Expresses relief and affection by hugging himself and saying 'I love you.'
Eases himself backwards slowly and carefully to open the jail house door, showing caution and control.
Shows an anguished expression as he pushes himself inside and slams the door, indicating emotional vulnerability but also determination.
Stands with his back against the door and sighs with relief, indicating awareness of danger and successful evasion.
Talks to himself affectionately and then self-corrects, showing a moment of emotional distraction.

Paints over a black face on an ashtray, then tacks up 'Wanted' posters including one of a black man but crumples it and throws it away, saying 'He's got enough trouble without a bunch of honkies chasing his ass all over Mexico.'
Carefully paints over the black face on the jockey ashtray to white, showing attention to detail and skill.
Studies the 'Wanted' posters and thoughtfully discards the one of a black man, showing judgment and consideration.
Helps Jim, a prisoner, to his feet after a crash and offers assistance.
Invites Jim to eat despite Jim's refusal, showing concern for his well-being.
Engages Jim in conversation and offers to play chess to pass the time.
Helps a prisoner who is hung over by unlocking the cell and assisting him to his feet.
Observes the prisoner's condition carefully and offers advice about eating and drinking.
Engages the prisoner in conversation to understand him better and suggests playing chess to connect.
Expresses determination to find out the reason behind the town's chaos, showing concern.
Refuses to take back a chess move despite advice, claiming responsibility for his actions.
Grabs his nose and begins sucking his thumb after admitting a mistake.
Determines there must be a reason behind the town being busted up and the sheriff killed, showing curiosity and resolve to find out.
Makes a poor chess move putting his queen in jeopardy, but refuses to take it back and accepts the consequences, showing confidence but questionable judgment.
Engages in playful competition with Jim, celebrates victory with a dance, and jokes with him.
Mocks Jim's drinking habit but in a teasing, not hostile way.
Calls Jim 'chump' after winning, boasting about his own skill.
Makes a winning chess move with flourish and confidently declares checkmate.
Challenges Jim to demonstrate skill and participates eagerly in a test of quickness.
Smiles victoriously after clasping hands over the king, showing confidence in his quickness.
Offers Jim a drink and shares a laugh with him.
Imitates a harp in a playful manner during storytelling.
Refers to a six-year-old kid as a 'little bastard' after being shot.
Clasps his hands over the king and smiles victoriously, showing confidence in a game or challenge.
His expression changes to surprise when the king is taken from under his hat, indicating a momentary lapse or being outsmarted.
Offers Jim a drink and engages in friendly conversation, showing social ease but not necessarily competence.
Narrates his backstory with humor and self-awareness, demonstrating intelligence and storytelling skill.
Admits to not being part of the main wagon train but trailing behind, indicating a less capable or less prestigious position.
Narrates the story with humor and tries to engage the audience despite their disinterest.
Cares for Jim by carrying him to bed and covering him with a blanket.
Narrates the story with humor and confidence, maintaining composure despite the dangerous situation.
Creates his own wagon circle when excluded from the main one, showing resourcefulness.
Tries to keep the audience engaged despite Jim falling asleep, showing awareness and control.
Carefully puts the sleeping Jim on his cot and covers him with a blanket, then prepares to go to sleep by putting out the kerosene lamp with a smile and calm demeanor.
Shares his own tobacco and rolls a cigarette with Jim, engaging in a casual, friendly interaction.
Expresses optimism about being accepted by the townspeople despite Jim's warning.
Uses a strained, high, breathy voice when speaking about his position, possibly indicating vulnerability or sincerity.
Carefully prepares his own cigarette with skill and attention to detail.
Confidently asserts that once he establishes himself, people will accept him despite opposition.
Ignores Jim's warning about the difficulty of winning over the townspeople, showing confidence in his own understanding of human nature.
Greets elderly woman politely despite her racist insult.
Intervenes to stop a group of children bullying one boy.
Engages playfully and helpfully with Mongo, preparing him for a dive and encouraging him.
Stops pumping and takes a break while Mongo is underwater, potentially neglecting Mongo's safety.
Politely greets an elderly woman despite her rude response, maintaining composure.
Closes his eyes and shakes his head after insult, then checks if Jim noticed, showing awareness and emotional control.
Intervenes to stop a fight among children, successfully dispersing aggressors and protecting the victim.
Organizes a playful treasure hunt and equips Mongo with a diving helmet and pump, demonstrating resourcefulness and leadership.
Stops pumping air for Mongo underwater and takes a break, potentially risking Mongo's safety.
Reassures Mongo about the cost despite Mongo not having money, saying 'Don't worry about the tariff, Pal, catch you later.'
Encourages Mongo to smile and enjoy the experience, showing friendliness and good-natured behavior.
Organizes and operates a complex photo stunt involving cannons and a diver, communicates clearly with Mongo, and manages the setup confidently.
Charges Mongo 25 cents for air in the diving suit but then dismisses the payment, showing some flexibility and understanding.
Uses humor and casual language ('smart as a '38 Buick') to ease tension and engage the audience.
Dismisses Mongo's strength and complains about lack of credit for inventing the Candygram.
Receives a pie from an elderly woman who had insulted him earlier, implying some level of forgiveness or tolerance.
Comments confidently on Mongo's strength and the invention of the Candygram, showing awareness and a sense of ownership.
Dismisses Mongo as 'nothing' despite Mongo's impressive physical presence, indicating a confident but possibly underestimating attitude.
Accepts gifts and apologies from townspeople graciously, responds politely and appreciatively.
Agrees to keep the elderly woman's visit a secret, showing trust and discretion.
Engages in friendly banter with Jim about his growing acceptance in town.
Accepts gifts and favors graciously and with good humor, showing social intelligence and confidence.
Responds to requests and interactions promptly and politely, demonstrating attentiveness and situational awareness.
Acknowledges the underground support and humorously comments on his growing popularity, showing self-awareness and confidence.
Accepts a secret note from Lili and respectfully goes to her dressing room alone.
Gives Lili a red rose as a romantic gesture.
Mumbles about his crushed hat after Leopold destroys it, showing a small moment of vulnerability.
Receives a secret note from Lili and plans to meet her alone after the show, showing awareness and discretion.
Hands his hat to Leopold who immediately crushes it, and Bart only mumbles about loving the hat instead of reacting more assertively.
Makes a lighthearted joke about the glare being eliminated.
Politely asks Lili to stop sucking his arm.
Declines more food and gently refuses Lili's whispered offer, citing responsibilities.
Makes a witty comment about eliminating the glare after the lights go out.
Politely points out discomfort when Lili is sucking his arm.
Declines more food and excuses himself to do heavy chores, showing responsibility and time management.
Engages in playful banter with Lili, showing social confidence.
Dismisses Lili's emotional plea and calls her a spectacle.
Frees Mongo by splashing water on him and telling him he is free.
Insists Mongo leave despite Mongo's affection and desire to stay.
Takes the writ from Jim and studies it carefully, showing awareness of legal matters.
Frees Mongo by splashing water on him and encouraging him to leave, demonstrating practical problem-solving and leadership.
Shows some uncertainty about recent events ('I'm not sure, but I think I invented pornography.'), indicating a moment of confusion or lack of clarity.
Tries to get Mongo to leave but fails, showing limited control over the situation.
Embraces Charlie gleefully upon meeting, showing friendly reunion.
Uses casual, teasing language with Charlie (e.g., 'shifty nigger', 'back off scamp'), indicating camaraderie and friendliness.
Plans to 'do a little snooping' at the railroad construction site, showing initiative but also potential risk-taking without consulting others.
Dismisses Mongo's question about lunch with a joking remark 'eat the horses', showing a lighthearted but somewhat dismissive attitude.
Suggests sneaking out to snoop on the railroad construction, showing initiative and strategic thinking.
Confidently embraces his role as sheriff despite others' doubts, demonstrating self-assurance.
Plans to eat the horses to manage resources until the stage arrives, indicating practical problem-solving.
Introduces Jim as his friend and describes him as 'cool'.
Receives friendly gestures and support from railroad workers who slap him on the back and rejoice.
Confidently asserts his authority as sheriff to Charlie.
Introduces Jim as his friend and remains composed when Charlie slaps Jim off.
Receives enthusiastic support from railroad workers, indicating respect and leadership.
Asserts his authority firmly and demands respect despite racial slurs.
Holds gun on Taggart and his men after they are disarmed, sarcastically encouraging applause for the Waco Kid.
Confidently asserts his authority as sheriff despite racial insults.
Calmly pulls out his gun and holds it on Taggart and his men after they are incapacitated.
Encourages the defeated men to applaud the Waco Kid, showing control of the situation.
Asks about the townspeople leaving and shows concern for the town's fate.
Recognizes the villain's poster as a desperate act and tries to reassure the townsfolk.
Asks for 24 hours to come up with a plan to save Rock Ridge, showing commitment and hope.
Recognizes the poster as a sign of a desperate enemy and understands the gravity of the situation.
Asks for 24 hours to devise a brilliant plan to save the town, showing confidence and leadership.
Plans to get closer to the target with Jim, showing cooperation and focus on the mission.
Mocks the Ku Klux Klanners by pretending to be a stereotypical plantation darkie to avoid harm.
Suggests getting closer to the target, showing tactical awareness.
Plays along with a dangerous situation by pretending to be a plantation darkie to avoid harm.
Expresses enjoyment after a violent act, but in a casual, somewhat dreary tone.
Uses humor and impersonation (Jesse Owens impression) to escape capture.
Acts cooperatively with Jim to evade pursuers, showing teamwork and trust.
Successfully infiltrates the enemy line using a clever disguise and a humorous fake qualification, gaining a badge.
Quickly adapts to a dangerous situation by fleeing and leading pursuers astray at a fork in the road.
Uses humor and quick thinking to cover a potentially compromising moment (black hand exposed).
Engages in physical confrontation (implied by muffled thuds and groans) without hesitation.
Jumps into the water with others, participates in baptism scene.
Punches Cutthroat unconscious to protect Jim.
Steals a horse with Jim, acknowledges it openly.
Quickly assesses the situation and jumps into the water with Jim to blend in with the crowd.
Responds to threat by punching Cutthroat unconscious, showing decisiveness and physical capability.
Notices the horse and seizes the opportunity to escape by stealing it.
Communicates clearly with Jim during the chase, urging to speed up after being spotted.
Reassures Charlie by whispering 'it's me, it's me...Bart' before giving instructions.
Covers Charlie's mouth to keep him quiet but allows brief moments to speak.
Gives clear, direct instructions to Charlie to organize resources and meet him.
Runs with Jim to escape danger, showing teamwork and trust.
Runs like lightning with Jim, easily outdistancing Taggart and his men.
Quietly and skillfully wakes Charlie without alerting others, then gives clear, strategic instructions to gather supplies and organize a meeting.
Uses a firm but controlled method (covering mouth) to keep Charlie silent, showing tactical awareness.
Tells Charlie to say hello and goodbye to maintain cover, showing attention to detail and psychological control.
Reassures townspeople by explaining the plan and showing confidence in their collective effort.
Tells Howard to trust him despite confusion and uncertainty.
Takes charge of the situation by organizing the townspeople to build a decoy town overnight to mislead the enemy.
Confidently reassures the confused townspeople and explains the plan clearly.
Rides off without explaining the plan initially, causing confusion among others.
Organizes railroad workers to help build the town, offering them land in return.
Refuses to accept discriminatory terms from Olson Johnson regarding who can settle.
Encourages the townsfolk to work together and motivates them to complete the project.
Organizes and motivates a diverse group of railroad workers to help build the town, successfully negotiating terms and inspiring collective effort.
Refuses to accept discriminatory demands from Olson Johnson, standing firm on inclusive principles.
Encourages urgency and focus as the work nears completion, showing leadership and awareness of potential problems.
Acknowledges the problem of no people in the replica town and makes a plan to create dummies to slow down attackers.
Responds to Olson's concern with a sarcastic 'A cute observation.'
Recognizes the problem that the town is missing people despite the perfect replica, showing awareness and quick thinking.
Formulates a plan to create perfect copies of themselves to slow down the attackers, demonstrating creativity and leadership.
Organizes the men quickly to implement the plan before the enemy arrives, showing decisiveness and confidence.
Organizes the setup of a toll booth on the prairie and directs others to prepare for incoming men.
Organizes and sets up a fake toll booth on the prairie to delay or confuse the approaching horde.
Directs Jim, Howard, and Samuel to unhitch the horses and prepare for the plan, showing leadership and foresight.
Anticipates the arrival of the horde and urges his team to hurry, demonstrating situational awareness and confidence.
Organizes townspeople to place dummies and prepares to lay dynamite with Jim.
Organizes townspeople to place dummies and directs Jim to lay dynamite, showing leadership and planning.
Not shown making mistakes or confusion in this excerpt; remains focused on task.
Encourages the group with enthusiasm ('Here we go. Hold your ears, folks. It's showtime.')
Acknowledges the problem with the broken wire and calmly seeks a solution by asking Jim to try shooting the dynamite
Recognizes the wire is broken and quickly suggests an alternative plan to Jim to set off the dynamite by shooting from a distance.
Pushes the plunger expecting an explosion but nothing happens, causing disappointment among the group.
Leads his group in a victorious attack, encouraging townspeople to join with enthusiasm.
Commands his group confidently to finish off the enemy after the explosion, leading the townspeople in a successful attack.
Fighting back to back with Jim, knocking out bad guys despite being punched in the stomach.
Responds to being punched with a hollow voice and demands fairness, then quickly regains composure and punches out his attacker.
Comments to Jim about their progress fighting their way up to 1938, showing awareness of their situation and maintaining composure amid chaos.
Picks up pie and smashes it into Lyle's face during chaotic fight.
Spots Hendley Lamarr sneaking out and takes off after him.
Spots Lamarr sneaking out and immediately pursues him on horseback, showing quick reaction and determination.
Takes off after the taxi without hesitation, demonstrating decisiveness and confidence.
Throws away guns and proposes to settle conflict with fists, indicating a preference for fair, direct confrontation.
Engages in a violent fight resulting in Lamarr's death.
Gallops up to the theatre, ties his horse confidently, and prepares to confront Lamarr.
Throws away his guns to settle the fight with fists, showing confidence and control.
Quickly reacts to Lamarr's gunfire by hurling himself to the ground, rolling, picking up his six-shooter, and firing in one smooth motion.
Speaks sincerely about being needed to protect innocent women and children and uphold justice.
Admits that his noble speech was not true and that he is leaving because it's getting dull.
Slaps Charlie's hand off while riding past.
Calmly assesses the situation after Hedley Lamarr's death and makes a dry, witty comment.
Decides to leave town confidently, stating his work is done and he is needed elsewhere.
Acknowledges the townspeople's disbelief with humor and honesty.
Does not engage in further conflict or explanation when challenged by townspeople, choosing to exit instead.
Pledges himself to Lili's bosom in a playful, somewhat insincere manner.
Turns around, takes off his hat and waves it to the townsfolk.
Says 'Keep the faith, niggers' to the townsfolk.
Smiles and invites Jim to ride along with him.
Turns around, takes off his hat and waves it to the townsfolk confidently.
Engages in a casual, friendly exchange with Jim and invites him to join, showing social ease and confidence.
Rides off quietly into the sunset with Jim, then calmly waits for a stagecoach hold-up, showing patience and composure.
Stares at Lili's bosom and makes a crude comment, indicating a lack of focus or professionalism.
Uses a racially insensitive phrase ('Keep the faith, niggers.') to the townsfolk, showing poor judgment and insensitivity.
